issues.description: The template repository defines a getter for the stock quantity with the name retrieveQuantity(), while other template code (Stock, Main comments) and the problem statement expect a conventional getter name getQuantity(). This name mismatch causes compilation errors in the provided template (calls to getQuantity() do not resolve). The solution repository uses getQuantity(), showing the intended API. The problem statement also explicitly asks students to "add getters for all the private fields", which implies the conventional getX naming convention. This inconsistency is unintentional and will block students from compiling and running the starter code and from following the intended design.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the getter in the template StockIngredient class from retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity(), and keep its return type as int. Update any references if necessary. This will align the template with the problem statement's expectation and with the solution reference, restoring a consistent API and allowing the template to compile.

issues.description: The StockIngredient.quantity field is accessed with inconsistent getter names across artifacts. The problem statement requires adding getters for private fields (and the class diagram implies a standard getter for quantity). The solution implementation defines getQuantity(), and other code (Stock.java and Main.java in the template) expects getQuantity(). However, the template's StockIngredient.java declares retrieveQuantity() instead of getQuantity(). This mismatch breaks the conceptual mapping for students (they are told to add getters and see code calling getQuantity()) and causes compilation confusion/error.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the template's StockIngredient.retrieveQuantity() method to getQuantity() so it matches the standard getter convention, the problem statement's instruction to add getters, and the usages in Stock.java/Main.java. Update any references if necessary. This aligns template and solution naming and removes student confusion and compilation errors.
